Today, I am grateful I ended up at NYU Fertility Center in the year 2000 with the best Doctor ever: Dr Licciardi (I just saw on their website he is still there and I know he is a great asset to NYU Fertility Center) I was surprised when I learned he wasn't the one conducting my retrieval but he called me and put me at ease about who was doing the retrieval I really thought Dr Licciardi's care was excellent during the process I definitely felt that he cared and I wasn't just another number in the factory He is compassionate, smart, caring, available, etc Based on my extensive research, I learned that Dr Grifo is one of the most prominent IVF experts in the country and that he has had personal experience with IVF in his own familyI (40 year old) am holding my miracle child after 10 years of infertility and IF treatments (previous patient at Cornell and Columbia (stay far away from here!!!)Dr Berkeley took my rare case (less than 1% of his patients) and believed they could help melike any Infertility clinic- it gets busy- but never felt like the cattle call at CornellI've sent several friends to Dr Berkely with confidence and would send my sister (if I had one! ) to him It was my first time going under anesthesia, and I was terrified--but the whole thing ended up being just as efficient as the rest of my care at NYU  She was good at making me feel comfortable with the process  For me, recovery wasn't bad  Apparently, my husband's sperm (which he provided a few weeks earlier and looked 'great' at the time) - did not come out of frozen in a good state Dr Leeds was my doctor and was honest with me about the chances for success and limits to the procedureDr Grifo is my phenomenal doctor who came highly recommended and has lived up to his word-of-mouth He knows these processes so well that after a cycle or two, he masterfully tailors the drugs to what the individual patient can tolerateDr Noyes is also freaking amazing Number two: she has had a great sense of humor, a jovial, approachable manner, and a clear underlying focus on results whenever I've interacted with her Dr Noyes is rigorous, meticulous, courageously honest about what patients can expect and should do, and dedicated to high performance standards Dr Noyes will cut through that insidious optimism and help you make statistically informed decisions The doctor who performed the ultrasound was kind, said everything was normal, and we got to take pictures and a video of our baby's heartbeat Dr Licciardi listened to us carefully, provided his recommendations clearly and confidently, and ultimately helped us conceive our first baby in three months of treatment! I would recommend Dr Licciardi to anyone looking for a warm, knowledgable, caring support on the journey to conception Dr Grifo was my doctor, and yes, while I didn't see him every cycle, he was always available by phone and my husband and I often set up calls with him to check in and he did design and adjust my meds with each cycle and day-to-day, especially towards the time of retrieval)  Overall, I thought NYU was efficient and professional, and I'm very pleased with my experience  My doctor was Dr Liccardi, who was very nice and knowledgable, and called me the day I started stims to make sure I was okWe had Dr Keefe, and he is awesome My doctor is amazing (Hodes-Wertz), the other docs I've interacted with are friendly and knowledgable,  and the nurses absolutely make the place Highly recommend!We are patients of Dr Grifo and couldn't have had a better experience and are sooo thankful for his expertise  Dr Grifo  is unbelievably brilliant, he gave us great advice along the way, he addressed all our questions and concerns, and their clinic is state-of-the-art in technical advancements I don't remember what Doctor handled our implantation- but she was fantastic  When I finally spoke to my doctor, I felt like she was talking down to me despite the fact that I am a healthcare professional and this isn't my first IVF  I felt like she couldn't even be bothered with explaining her decision to me The doctors are amazing, and very approachable

I've heard bad things about Cornell (and nothing positive), so I wouldn't recommend them either Every time we receive a bill it is like PTSD about our past failed cycles 4) They told me that I need to book an appointment with Dr Berkley to complain about all of the above* Overall while I am sure that Dr Berkley is an expert in the infertility treatment, I personally did not feel that his care was different/exceptional from other physicians and that NYU internal workflow/communication was the worst I have ever seen I had repeated failed cycles here, and questioned their earlier representations to me I found Dr Grifo's behavior to be unprofessional and beneath the standards I would expect for a physician - despite the fact that he delayed my procedure due to their on-the-spot demands for money - he had the gall and distaste to say to me that he could have made $3,000 during the time he was speaking to me I found the experience traumatic and, as mentioned earlier, repeated cycles were entirely unsuccessful My dr was DR Keefe, who spend some time with us during initial consultation, however it was very difficult to get a hold of him directly for any questions after that He was inaccessible and his secretary at the time was new and not helpful  The first problem occurred when the secretary gave me the wrong appointment time and date  It was in her handwriting, so she knew she wrote it wrong and all she could do was apologize profusely

Dr Licciardi was my doctor but I saw him only twice during the process We met at the consult and then he preformed one ultrasound He was always accessible by phone and email, and he called me several times to keep me updated and to check on me He seems to know exactly what to do in more difficult situations like mine where the body doesn't react to the medicine quickly By the time they had me on ganirelix I did feel twinges in my abdomen and felt bloated Note:  Dr Noyes is the most statistically oriented of the doctors with whom I've interacted"I later emailed Dr Noyes (she didn't respond) and called the office to clarify I only met with Dr Noyes once during the process  When I spoke to others at the office, they kept telling me to call her  I felt like i was being jerked around All of that, it took them 45 minutes to figure out, and after he was told numerous times that he did not have an appointment  I felt that Dr Berkley was not involved in the decision making/ guidance after the initial visit  * I and the NYU staff was not able to communicate with Dr Berkley in regards to issue that were time sensitive Twelve thumbs up for Dr Licciardi and his staffI had a nightmarish experience at this center, and with Dr Grifo  We went in for our first visit with Dr Grifo and, even though I had an incredibly large history file for him to review, he knew exactly what to try from day 1 He was open to trying new things, and answered every question I sent, at any time of day

Second, no one is going to hold your hand during the process You owe it to your future self to go to the best provider Do your research and be proactive, but love yourself no matter what happens He truly cares about his patients and wants the best for them One of the most important things to look for is that the doctor studies your charts after each test and adjusts the medication and protocol accordingly to maximize your chances for a positive outcome  I hope to go back for a sibling and hope that if you go here you walk away with your miracle Please note, it has never taken another Doc more than 1 tryWould recommend, would do again, and will definitely go to NYU for any future fertility care I may need in the future  I recommend bringing your SO (if you have one) so that you can do your paperwork together under supervision Also, I strongly recommend icing to help make the shots more bearable  When they determine you are ready, they'll tell you a specific time to take your trigger shot; your procedure will be 35 hrs later Note - the retrieval doctor is unlikely to be *your* doctor (from the consult); fine by me, but some people may not realize this going in  I also think a call at least once during the cycle from the doctor of your initial consult would help immensely to improve 'feel Just see that you are above 40 and tell you that your only hope is to use donor eggs Still no certainties what will happen, but they skills gave me the best chance possible Look instead at the most recent literature from the medical community and to sources you can trust for expert and accurate advice The NYU clinic is associated with one of the best research universities in the world after all Still, it's important to keep in mind that this process is basically a scientific miracle I am impressed with his intellect and dedication to continuing research in fertility He is exactly who you want on your make-a-baby team Number 1: Who cares!? She is a scientist and surgeon, not a therapist I also highly recommend Dr Fino - another experienced straight shooter who will not BS you about what to expect And if you have Dr Grifo, definitely let him do whatever he thinks best with your drug protocol Empower yourselves and use the team of doctors to your advantage Way better than reading fertility forums which tend to be overly optimisticFrom a donor perspective: make sure to do your research! This was a great resource for me, straight from the New York Department of Health: health Consider where you go carefully - your health matters, too"Me: "Ok, so I guess I should have this baby and get the vaccines right after and then I won't be getting pregnant within 30 days?"Nurse: "Well you need to get the vaccine before you get pregnant, so you don't want to wait Why not?! So bizarreDr Licciardi is absolutely amazing His warmth and understanding put us at ease right away  Just wish the rest of the experience was more pleasant and straight forwardI agree with the others regarding doctors/nurses not giving much attention to you or your future Thank you, NYU  In this consultation, he/she first reviews your medical history and talks you through it, and also provides a detailed overview of the process, and statistical chances of success)  After that, you're ready to start whenever you're ready  Once the doctor doing your ultrasound deems you "ready," they'll schedule your retrieval procedure, usually two days later, and instruct you to take a trigger shot, diagram of the female reproductive system), with the most relevant info (dos and don'ts) kind of mixed in easy to forget  I will add my two cents and will try to be as fair and intelligent as possible in my thoughts, because, if you are reading this, you are contemplating some big stuff in your life!Disclaimer: my partner and I did this electively - we froze our embryos - and we are not trying to conceive at this time  I can say that Dr Grifo is awesome, too, because I had some contact with him also  You will be making regular visits, and it is the rest of the staff that you will be working with, and you will be super hormone'd up and extra sensitive, to boot  Also, you feel a little bit like cattle, going through the process  Nobody will ever simply ask you how you are feeling  (I'm all for it because it will help future couples conceive, but if you don't want a student in there, just speak up and say so  Try not to over-worry this partI had the best experience here! I love the team and everything went so smoothly! I highly recommend you go to NYU you will not regret it I honestly cannot say enough about my experience here Yes, you may not see your actual doc often - that's how it works at all fertility clinicsthis is especially impressive since everyone else had no idea how to proceedthey deal with facts and are there to help give you the highest probability of having a baby  When you go to the best of the best, you DO get different results  Let them do what they do besthelp give you the greatest gift of life  They work with Walgreens and Livestrong to get you all of your hormones free of charge He's truly sweet and honestly caring, on top of being an amazing expert  The MDs do not seem invested in patient care

Get there at 7 am to avoid the wait for blood work You have to go into this knowing that you are going to drop thousands of dollars Recommendations for NYU:  I think the biggest issue for NYU in terms of 'feel' is the lack of a single point of contact for your cycle No effort to try anything  They "explain" things to you as if you work there and do all these things every day, but most of us do each of the things we need to do in this process one time and have no idea what NYU is talking about I think it's hard to find someone in New York who doesn't just care about the money and know there will also be lots of patients in the pipeline, even if they get some bad reviews) The trouble with egg freezing is that people should probably have ~20 eggs banked if they donate at age 36-37 and want a 50% chance at a live birth Having a child genetically related to oneself following cancer or into one's 40s is a triumph of technology over the harsher side of nature I read on here that maybe she isn't always warm and fuzzy If you are a logical, statistical thinker, you will get sick of all the anecdotal and narrative evidence batted around in fertility forums and between moms There are medical risks associated with egg donation, and donors should go through the procedure fully informed of those risks I do not feel confident that the health of donors is given enough consideration at NYU - there are other options in the city"Nurse: "If you're not going to follow our advice to get the vaccine, you'll need to sign a waiver saying you understand the risksMy experience with Yelp reviews is that they are mostly either excellent or disastrous, and so I am writing to give a more nuanced picture There was a training session to explain the egg freezing process and ask questions, as all the language around different hormones and cycles can be overwhelmingDespite this, I think my doctor is great payment plan, timing, your chart and what's missing, etc We couldn't be happier with the care we received there  I'll briefly describe the steps of their egg freezing cycle:  first, you go in for bloodwork on day 2/3  Before you leave, you get your egg count  But unfortunately, you spend very little of your time here with your doc  My other negative is that they really just don't prepare you for the enormity of what you are going through  I would read up on IVF, the hormones, the injections you give yourself, the pain and discomfort that you will experience, and the procedure, before you proceed  They really don't provide the support for the emotions that you will experience, or even the physical pain, so you have to find this support elsewhere   When I think about it, this is crazy to me, because, by all accounts, stress and anxiety are really bad for fertility, but they don't seem to give a crap about any stress or anxiety you are feeling  I think it will make you crazy to second-guess the doctors here, but hey, hormones make you do crazy things!  Anything having to do with making babies is an inexact science, that's just the way it isTo anyone considering using NYU, keep in mind that the NYU team isn't there for emotional support I called the number on the statement to inquire about the additional $950, she tells me that there's no record of the $6950 payment Puts me on hold, she than comes back to say that I need to call the NYU fertility office and have them release the $950 to be paid to the anesthesiologist Wouldn't send my friends/relatives any place else!

Egg quality is a mystery until you make embryos Sixth, be realisticDr Licciardi is an angel Other clinics often make you follow a generic protocol and shrug when you don't get results even though they should know that every body reacts differently to the medicine And they ask for $500 to give you your own eggs if you decide to transfer them elsewhere Initial consult w/ Dr Noyes"  Later, the call comes with info about how much medication to take You are also told your egg count (mine was 12) To be realistic about it: shooting yourself with hormones every day is grueling I would advise anyone above 40 (women) NOT to pursue treatment here Or else never would I choose to work with these physicians  But with very few (like one person) exceptions, they don't care about you at all  Maybe try CCRM?  Or get out of New York if you can He's got the art side of this process down Although this procedure is elective, donors should be entitled to understand potential medical complications I'll update as those bills come in (Those are LIVE vaccines which are NOT given during pregnancy!)Nurse: "You need to go to a clinic to get the MMR and chickenpox vaccines Just wait 30 days to get pregnant  In the meantime, after speaking with someone below her at the office, I called insurance myself and relayed all the info - Insurance told me to go ahead with the procedureBelow is the brief summary of our experience with NYU  * I only spoke with Dr Berkley once on the initial visit  I'd look for other options Yes they don't hold your hand but they really deliver  Then you do an initial consultation with the doctor you chose  (They also will check your insurance for you to see if any of the medications are covered  Then, that afternoon, a nurse will call you, give you your estrogen levels, and give you instructions on what to take for then next few days and when to come back  Amen, sister!  You are so right on that  It is also an emerging and changing field  There may be students in some of your appointments  Needles have come a LONG way  The anesthesiologist stays with you the whole time  Which is, after all, their job Apparently he is only part time at NYU and also has another practice

I also remember a very caring and nice nurse, I am not sure I am spelling her name properly: Nurse Oana (I think she was from Romania or an Eastern European country, not sure) anyway, all the nurses were very supportive during this emotional journey They were all excellent She was responsive, knowledgeable and easy to work with3 Orientation:  This provided useful information on how everything would proceed  That was the most important part for me  So, it's pretty clear what they really care about I was confused because I'd initially been told I'd just need the first and 48-hour tests, but the nurse said it was necessary to confirm things were moving successfullyI've recently did my first ever IVF cycle at NYU and my experience was really great! Nurses and staff were really efficient, straight to the point and nice) in her two main points: 1)  If you want results, you are as likely to get them here as anywhere else2)  They are NOT into giving "more emotional type support to their clients" Phone calls post-testing or procedure have always been timely, and they make sure you understand all instructions The nurses are helpful, especially Carol and Andrea and will answer your questions and call you back

Every phone/email interaction took no less than THREE tries  She finally called me back over a week later and told me she had been on vacation - apparently no one was covering for her and no one knew she was on vacation  When the woman from NYU returned from vacation and returned my call, she became upset with me because I had spoken to someone else in her department in billing!  It was really quite odd

Meet patient coordinator:  She was supposed to be my main point of contact over the next few weeks, though after paperwork/insurance was handled, I never spoke with her again 1/10 - Went back for another draw, got a call same-day from a nurse  I left message after message

They have a great team and I have to thank them for having given me the most precious gift I have: my daughter I had an excellent experience, but I can see why some people may have complaints Actually, it gave me comfort to know that the center is a well oiled machine All of the doctors are highly skilled with decades of experience so you will always be in great handsFourth, you will get excellent results My insurer was giving me the runaround and I couldn't wait any longerI am happy to say that I had a good experience with Dr Grifo at NYU and much better results than at another clinic (which I also reviewed)  I loved the whole clinic - minus a nurse or two- but on the whole- have loved my experience with them- ans again- this wasn't my first time aroundGenetic counselor, Andria was the only bright spot at this clinic (have been to 3 clinics at this point) When it got sent to me, more than half of the records were missing, but luckily the few items I needed where thereI chose NYU for my egg freezing because they are reputed to be the top facility for this procedure in the United States, if not the world  I was NOT disappointed!  In every step of the process, I was greeted with warm, friendly, attentive nurses and methodical doctors   You will feel like a product on an assembly line, but that's a good thing; you'll get the impression that NYU has done this many, many times before The morning visits were smooth and calm  Monitoring is something you'll be doing a lot of; it's quick (~20 min), and then you are on your way (maybe leading to the factory feel that some have reported, but I liked the expediency)About monitoring:  I felt like the nurses were great, caring and competent  Monitoring also makes you feel like you're in a spy movie; every day you are told to "await a phone call with further instructions About the shots:  Mixing Menopur takes a lot more time than expected!  Prepare to spend ~20 min each night setting everything up and take extra precautions to ensure you are doing it right Recovery: Once you have demonstrated your vitals are ok and you can use the bathroom on your own they send you out with a few docs about what to do/not to do and look for over the next week Overall, I was lucky not to have significant side effects from any part of the process or procedure Overall I would consider the experience generally positive due to the quality of people at NYU and feeling in safe hands  If they could somehow ensure a single, constant person greeted you each day for monitoring and later called you with instructions, it might feel a bit more personalized  They treat you like nameless, faceless cattle because that is what you are to them  People who are "coordinating" things say things like, "Did you tell so and so?" And you're thinking "I emailed every person with an email address, am I supposed to personally call every person whose name I've ever heard at NYU until I reach them after going through the switchboard? Isn't that, perhaps, your job? They are, of course, totally on top of billing - that part is always very clear and taken care of first and foremost This demonstrates to me that they did their job wellAsk questions and do your research intelligently: The NY Department of Health guidebook for egg donors mentioned by another reviewer is already 20 years old (1998!) and hasn't been updated since They do need improvement in some areas but are unlike commercial clinics that might look fancier but are exclusively for-profit I was laughing and talking about gelato as I waited for the anesthesia to kick in Then I had an effortless, painless recovery I wish they'd waited until after the ultrasound, so I could have avoided an unnecessary blood draw and bruised arm This place is a mill, they treat you like cattle But this is not even my main complaint It was well organized and although there are a lot of people handling you and your visits, I felt they were competent and everything was done professionally I had a friend help me with this process, but the Center should be able to provide more training and support at this point I recommended a friend to the Center who had a similar experienceI think the doctors are top-notch here and they are worth coming here for, but the support staff needs reorganizationThe nurses are good at responding to voicemails, but their response is always to tell you to speak with billingAlso - I would skip the Recombine Genetic testing that they recommend here 1) You feel like you are in a vacuum But, they don't realize that the phone tag play is pretty awful I guarantee that they will not pick up your call (no matter which number you call), and you leave a vm, and if you ever miss their callback, good luck because when you call back, that will go to vm againGreat Doctors, but HORRIBLE customer service IVF is a very difficult process physically and emotionally, but the team at NYU is caring, knowledgeable and very well coordinated The give clear, individualized instructions and are available to answer questions The nurses are caring and compassionate and the embryology team is very good They are clear in their results and straightforward On my last day there I receive a warm goodbye and I felt cared for And pregnant, which I am deeply grateful to the team there for Kind, helpful, compassionate, human I was dreading ER but my experience in OR was great! No pain after and nurses were very comforting when I woke up Overall the whole process was very smooth and much easier than I originally expected NYU has a great team of doctors, nurses, embryologists - I was really impressed  (This is a long review, but I wanted to describe the whole experience  Then, he/she does an examination to make sure everything looks in order down there)  You pick a pharmacy (I highly recommend Apthorp -- they deliver!), and NYU will call in your prescriptions  You go in for bloodwork on your day 2, and then that afternoon, if you're bloodwork is solid, you're cleared to start meds and they'll tell you exactly what to take and when, and when to come back into the office  The next day, a nurse calls you and tells you how many of those were able to be freezed, and of those, how many are mature  Overall, I was very pleased with the experience  It's true that you don't see the doctor much, if at all, after your initial consult, but I really did not mind as every doctor I saw (they rotate in the mornings to do the ultrasounds) was very competent and nice and I never felt that I was not in good hands  There is definitely a "factory" feel to the process, and sometimes you feel guilty holding up the process by asking questions (they just move that fast), but I actually overall appreciated that quality, because it made the entire experience very efficient and not much of an intrusion into my daily routine  I did at times wish I had a direct line to someone, but I realize they are busy treating patients and not sitting by the phone  In terms of areas for improvement, my only complaint would be the orientation process  Also, the nurse that did our orientation (both times -- I attended twice since I waited so long) was a bit strange and I thought somewhat inappropriate, but most importantly, long-winded and slow, making it an unhelpful 3 hours of my workday  I think the orientation should be shortened by half with the emphasis on 1) do's and don't's during the cycle; and 2) a quick demonstration of how to administer the shots (not an endless one, as I experienced, since there are videos onlineI am surprised to see so few reviews here of this clinic   So I might have had higher expectations for this place, having not been in a situation where I felt that I had no other options  One of the best doctors I've ever worked with  If I had once piece of feedback for this place, it would be to please only hire people with a decent bedside manner, especially those who work directly with patients  Sometimes it felt like they were taking the "care" out of medical careThe good stuff is: they know what they are doing, and I believe they are actually one of the clinics who helped make this whole field in the first place)Another "good" thing, if you can call it that, is that the injections that you give yourself - that you will dread - are really no bigs!  You can just watch the training videos a bunch of times til you feel comfortable doing it (that's what I did)  They put you in what they call, and I am not kidding, "twilight sedation", which is great  The sedation is awesome  It is all the stuff Michael Jackson was into :)  My recovery was also no bigs at all - can't say that I had any issues with that Everyone here is efficient and kind They often remember you (not sure how when they see hundreds of patients), and I've never felt unwelcome or rushed Not only am I confident they are doing everything I need medically, but I feel genuinely cared for by nursing staff when I'm there   We decided to travel to New York and try NYU because they have one of the highest success rates in the world  Our first clinic was definitely giving more emotional type support to their clients, but that got us no where in the end  NYU is the best at what they doThank you to the entire NYU team for not giving up on us when everyone else did!  We are very thankful But the doctors don't really pay you much attention, literally running from room to room every morning I've heard other places are similar- ie feels like a factory- so I'm not sure if this is standard for large hospitals that have good reputation for fertility treatmentThis is an excellent fertility center The place is super-organized, morning monitoring is really efficient and quick (unlike, say, Columbia)  In the recovery room after the retrieval procedure, the nurses were making fun of on of the patient's who was experiencing hallucinations after the anesthesia

This review comes perhaps after 19 years, as at the time there was no internet I was cursing the center's name during my first injection as I felt that they could have done more to prepare me In my case, they charged me their cash rate and it took me 4 months and hours of my time to get them to refund the overcharge (the difference between the cash rate and the insurance-negotiated rate that I should have paid)Administrative support here was probably the worst part of this clinic Was frustrating to schedule appointments and get questions answered by the nurses  No reason to mess up your cycle because you forgot a vial or took the wrong meds I did not accept Tylenol and felt like I had very bad cramps for the rest of the day but they improved by day 2 I suspect that this is the norm and so want to emphasize it since most boards are filled with negative experiences  I was *extremely* frustrated by this and consider it a huge fault of NYU that they did not inform us of this possibility (there was ample time for my husband to come back to provide more specimens)  On the negative side: the front office is extremely disorganized (don't discount other reviews about this; be vigilant about your paperwork and double check everything!) They don't really care about your financial and don't listen when you point out their mistakesI really can't say anything positive  They make an already very stressful process really more as stressful as possible and they just don't seem to care Many of the rest don't even have direct phone numbers - so it is sort of a ridiculous joke trying to reach people at various critical stages  I was annoyed when I realized this, but I can't say I was surprisedOne of the nurses (there are three) was troubled by my questions related to potential medical risks for donors, and expressed this There's also no online portal to check your own labs And when we contact the billing center to discuss (more than 10 times at this point), they claim there is some secret "Accounts Receivable" person who makes all the decisions who we are not allowed to talk to directly NYU Fertility Center is inhumane and really unpleasant to deal with The most difficult part of the process is the first time you come home with all the prescriptions and needles and you have to inject yourself for the first time  Their default start of conversation is always to ask "did you speak with billing?"  I've learned that if you press them, sometimes they will actually  look in your chart and see that there really is no need to speak with billing But, If I had waited, I would have missed that month's window  I've at various times waited two hours to be seen during morning monitoring - and double checked to see if my name had been called - have been told no, it hadn't, and then upon seeing the nurse, have been told that i was called earlier Unfortunately, it seems that the staff does not communicate very well   It's very stressful When i called Recombine, they told me they could reduce the payment, but refused to issue a new bill for me stating this They in the end explained how the lab was not ready that day, and they didn't know till that morning  * Terrible internal communication between the NYU staff (physicians and nurses) as I was repeatedly told erroneous or conflicting information/guidance  Such a shame they can't treat their patients betterWe've been around the block to different centers, and the people here are the absolute top  After that, you sign up for one of their egg freeze "orientations," which is a 2-3 hour presentation by a nurse about the details of the process (this was probably the weakest link in the experience, more on that below  This was no issue as Apthorp will deliver same day, even when you call late afternoon  The day of the retrieval, plan to spend 3 hours at the place -- an hour to change/talk to the anesthesiologist/wait around, 10-15 minutes for the procedure, and about 45 mins to an hour of recovery, where they give you water and crackers, and maybe pain meds if you need them for cramps I thought it was long and drawn out and filled with a lot of useless info (e They were beyond rude and horrendous to me  I had a few bad experiences with the staff, especially this super mean lady in the recovery room, OF ALL PLACES (when you are waking up from the anesthesia, from your procedure)  -- dang!  She was just super gruff and mean, and at one point just walked away while I was sitting alone and crying, during my intake for the procedure, when I was anxious and scared  I overheard a couple other ladies questioning their medicine doses and the timing of their procedures, and I just would caution against going down that roadThe other "good" thing, if you can call it that, is that the procedure, which I spent a lot of time dreading, it no bigs eitherSo, the bottom line for me is: this is a results-oriented medical clinic that will not hold your hand through any of thisI'm not a big poster, but I feel compelled to do so here - especially given some of these bad reviews If you have an emergency, leave a message via the call center and someone gets back you right away Very frustrating when you think that bill is paid and they hit you with another one out of nowhere So I called the NYU fertility billing office, of course they leave a voicemail at 5pm when they close Figure out a better system because this is unfair to your patients In the end the doctors and nurses all know what they are doing and you can trust them - but the communication is lacking and frustrating for a patient who has never gone through fertility treatment beforeSTAY AWAY FROM NYU! Horrible facility  My labs were sent to two different lab facilities on the same day and I was charged two co-pays, but nobody knew why they were sent to two facilities and why I was charged twice  I was not confident in my physician, I was not confident in her staff and I was not confident in the billingThe nurses gossip about the MDs constantly  The weekend nurses had made multiple mistakes regarding when I come in and when I take my medication The entire process was disappointing

Here are a few points to consider:First, it is a factory but an organized one  You may see the same nurses during blood work, but often they are different Third, your doctor may not do the actual retrieval They seem to make up prices out of thin air Most places charge $0-35 for this, which literally involves just pulling your vials from storage Be aware!I also encountered issues with NYU's and specifically the anesthesiology department's billing practices Found out after the fact only a tiny 5 ft, 100 lb woman should be on a 2 Also did a saline sonogram here, and there were literally chunks of my cervix on the floor after because it took the Doc FOUR tries to get the speculum and catheter in properly They kept saying they were sent via mail, but after me calling every week for over a month the admin realized the folder had been sitting on a desk but never picked up  The surgical procedure itself was a breezeExperience at NYU Fertility Center in May 2018; I was 35 Process begins!  You show up for monitoring (blood draw + ultrasound) on day 2 of your period  The ultrasound was always done by a doctor (though not always *your* doctor) When you get there, it's a quick review of your medical history before setting you up on a surgical chair (w/ very high stirrups) This was told to me by 2 separate providers in this same practice  It's a factory Examples: Few of them have email address (at least that they will provide) The way this clinic is set this up, patients have access to second, third, and fourth opinions during their cycles This is when I myself started to get concerned I found out I was pregnant a couple days before my appointment at NYU They took blood for genetic carrier screening and many other things they didn't tell me about beforehand She said I had to return in a week for an ultrasound, although it would be too early to see a heartbeat, and I'd need another ultrasound the next week to look for a heartbeat This was the first I'd heard of this The nurse didn't wash her hands or use gloves to prep the ultrasound probe (and she touched door knobs and a trash can) The nurse said my blood from 1/20 wasn't run since the doctor saw what she needed on the ultrasound"Me: "But I'm 6 weeks pregnant so what am I supposed to do?"Nurse: "It's up to you The same nurse (I think) said that nurses don't look at patients' records when they call with test results I won't be going back, as the potential for great medical error with this system is alarming The invoices are jibberish, but they keep sending them to usAnd I've found that billing only returns calls about 1 out of 4 times  Several months ago, I was told that I had to speak with a particular person at billing before I had a procedure Others I've spoken with have also experienced it  I was previously tested at another place and that should have been enough Dr Berkeley will talk to you on the first day (and that's it), and after that, you will most likely only communicate with either nurses, coordinators, billing department, more nurses, and a 'day of' doctor But since they don't talk to each other, you are always told different story  The Doctors are amazing, but the customer service and billing/administration is so bad I would just go someplace else if I had to do it all over again  When you call you NEVER get the actual folks at NYU Fertility, it just goes to an answering service over and over again  The service says someone will call you back within 3 hours and that never, ever happens  You have to constantly follow-up  My husband and I got some tests done here and it was extremely expensive, even though the facility and lab were both in-networkNYU Fertility Center changed my life  (It's usually in 1-2 days, always in the mornings between 7-9 am)  Every morning you go in, they do bloodwork, and most often they will do an ultrasound also to check how you are responding to the stims  The nurse will call and tell you precisely when to take the trigger shot, as your procedure in the OR will be timed exactly to this time  In the mornings when I went in, I would usually arrive around 8 am, and I rarely had to wait more than 5-10 minutes  If you have questions in the process, you call the nurse's hotline and someone will call you back within 2-3 hours But, more so, their billing felt incredibly disorganized I have never experienced a more callous, money-hungry experience as a patient and would never return to this clinic again  (I suggest hooking up with someone who has been through it before and putting them on speed-dial on your phone)  They're not about that  They are tiny now They are very organized and know exactly where you are/what you need in every cycleAll and all my experience at this facility was mediocre She states that the $950 is extra and told me to call another department But they are busy and sometimes it takes a full day for them to get back to you which is nerve wracking when dealing with self administered scheduled shots Billing does not call you back unless you hound them Maybe a smaller facility will be more hands on but have less caregivers which may cause other issues  I have been to many different places and I have never seen a more disorganized place Everything is digital, and everyone is on board at all times  They seem to be just coasting through the process

Life Is full of surprises as now 19 years after, my daughter is a freshman at NYU! I think Dr Licciardi wanted to manage my expectations because he told me to expect 10-14 eggs, but 22 were retrieved and 20 mature eggs were frozen (age 36) What this actually means I really don't know because Dr Licciardi made it clear that there are no guarantees I'm going to do another cycle because more eggs = higher percentage of a positive outcome He changed my life! I emphatically recommend him!! In the end, I had much better results than the first time at another clinic due to the above attention to detail and correct adjustments to the meds made along the way She was prepared for our session, explained our options clearly, and was able to order the necessary tests to help us build our probe (that we eventually used for a successful pregnancy via IVF)  I am now one day post-op and have no pain at all Before starting I wish I knew: (a) you can't exercise during the protocol OR for another 10-14 days afterwards! (b) The process is a big deal I would have been pleased with this, except that they needed to use ICSI for fertilization' However - my main goal was to go through this process in safe hands and I felt that was the case with NYU[They also misrepresented the number of eggs they froze AND the number of embryos I produced (presumably so it my results would look/sound better) - luckily I switched facilities and my new Dr straightened this outI am writing this review 5 years after having my eggs frozen at NYU I just thawed and fertilized the eggs (at a different facility as I have moved) and had higher than average success rates 7 of the 9 eggs successfully thawed and 6 were successfully fertilized (They do freeze the immature eggs, but at the moment, there is no way to get a human egg to mature outside of the ovary Research is ongoing, so they freeze the immature eggs in hopes that fertility science has had some breakthroughs by the time the eggs are thawed for use My retrievals consistently went up under his careful monitoring and I didn't even do the acupuncture or yogaAs for having a whole team of doctors available:  this is so much better than going back to the same person over and over again She suggested because of irregular cycles I go straight to a fertility center for testing and potential medication They care for pregnancies up to 10 weeks, so I figured I'd stick with them in case of miscarriage I wish they'd told me which tests they were running, since many were repeats of tests I'd had done recently and have records for 1/5 - Went back, had the blood draw, got a call same-day to say that my hCG had doubled and my pregnancy was progressing well (Ok, so why am I here going through all these blood tests if we're not going to actually do anything? Progesterone supplementation is controversial, but it would have been nice to at least have been given the chance to discuss with my doctor"Me: "Ok well it's too late for that now, and I can't get the vaccines because I'm pregnant My egg freezing procedure was successful and was seamless 2) My husband called 2 weeks prior (and I also wrote them an email) to confirm his appointment for providing his semen, and sure enough, they didn't have his name for that day  This was over six months ago and we are still trying to resolve it I did 6 cycles there and each one was fine-tuned to my response with each cycleI did one egg freeze cycle here and my review is based on that)  But overall, I'm extremely pleased with my experience and highly recommend NYU to anyone considering an egg freeze cycleI totally agree with the previous reviewer (G  He made an immediate connection with us and I really value that  I wanted to tattoo my name and date of birth on my forehead, from getting asked so many times  We didnt give up, but a few months later, our in-state fertility clinic dropped us after the 5th IVF because they couldn't figure out what was wrong  After learning a lot through our 6th IVF, we did another  2 IVFs with successful resultsI had 3 unsuccessful IUIs and one successful IVF frozen with PGD testing Only one embryo came back for implantation- but we have a healthy beautiful baby girl - now three weeks old The doctor who ended up giving the ultrasound asked why I came in so late In the end we are happy with our IVF baby girl and it was worth any aggravation we had at the time  She was pushing me to do a frozen embryo transfer, but I wanted a fresh cycle We did 4 IVF cycles at Columbia, had consultations and Cornell and at New Hope, and then found NYU NYU was sooooo much better than any of the above In particular, we loved Dr Keefe

I decided on NYU after doing a lot of research on egg freezing I'm doing this knowing that I have no control over the future outcome Did 3 letrozole cycles here, and had to ask after every failure to up my dosage (started at 2 Don't seem like a Doc even reviewed my cycle records until I asked She also smartly rejected my initial low AMH results (88 after I stopped bc for 2 months  Instead, we ended up spending a LOT of money on ICSI, and also being concerned /frustrated that we had to choose among a poor sperm sample  Also - I was extremely disappointed that NYU did not recommend we provide multiple sperm samples, which led us to need ICSI One word of caution to people planning to freeze their eggs for future use:  it's fairly common to get between 5 and 10 eggs per retrieval, some percentage of which may not be mature enough to freeze Demand this (There are studies about behavioral problems in chicks and rats exposed to ultrasound in utero, so I'm trying to limit ultrasounds She balked and said it was essential I do the early ultrasound because my blood test numbers had been low and there was concern about my pregnancy being viable She said my progesterone from the 1/3 and 1/5 tests was too low She said I was not immune to chicken pox, measles, or rubella (Idk how this is possible because I caught chickenpox and had two MMR vaccinesWe went through several painful failed IVF rounds here  And the whole thing would take no more than 20/25 mins if we did an ultrasound, and 5-10 if it was bloodwork only  We had several failed attempts to have a child in the state we live in  We are now expecting our first baby soon and couldn't say enough positive things about NYU and specifically Dr Grifo We would have an appointment with him regarding the IVF and it would get cancelled last minute and we had a first ultrasound appointment of fetus scheduled with him that also got cancelled  Ultimately, I decided not to have my procedure done here, because I don't trust them at all

I felt completely unprepared when it was time to do my first injection I read the directions and then watched the videos It probably took me an hour to do my first two injections Fast forward to Day 4, I was a pro at administering the injections (less than 10 minutes) Dr Grifo does exactly that  We did two rounds of IVF and we able to get my daughter5, then went to 5, and then 77) noting birth control pills sometimes affect them; AMH bumped to 1  On my protocol I was on maximum Menopur (450 per day) I started taking ganirelix to prevent ovulation around day 6  Personally I didn't feel much the first 5 days of stims Extraction Results:  I ended up w/12 eggs; 11 fertilized, 7 became embryos & 3 were viable  I assumed the patient coordinator would be that, but I didn't interact with her again once I started my cycleThis place will force you basically to use donor eggs if you are above age 40I have undergone three egg retrieval cycles here This guy does not quitgov/publicatio…I was on track to move forward with this procedure but ultimately decided not to do it at NYU)I contacted our health plan's fertility nurse when my husband & I decided to conceive1/3 - First appointment, chatted with Dr Noyes, had a blood draw to confirm pregnancy The nurse called me same-day with my hCG level and said to come back in 2 days for a repeat to confirm my levels were doubling They told me to come back the following week for another blood draw) I said I'd prefer to wait until I was far enough to find a heartbeat, so I could just have one ultrasound instead of two I asked her for my progesterone results from today's blood tests, and she said it wasn't taken She said they didn't check because Dr Noyes "doesn't believe in supplementing with progesterone" to prevent miscarriage)1/20 - Had a blood draw and transvaginal ultrasound I asked her to re-do it in a sanitary way, as I've developed infections from ultrasounds previously She said we still needed a repeat ultrasound in a week, but didn't clarify why1/22 - Called to get my test results from 1/20 The nurse gave me the results from an earlier blood test that I hadn't received before My titers were checked a few years ago when I volunteered in a hospital and came back showing immunity) But anyway, the nurse said I needed to get the MMR and varicella vaccines ASAP and wait 30 days to get pregnant  As a patient, I've continued to experience this type of disorganization with each cycle 3) I was told that I could adjust the timing of my transfer with pills When I reached out to one of the coordinators to book the transfer date and/or to get the prescription for the pill, she said there is nothing she can do until we have the PGS result But, when I got the PGS result, I then was told (by a different nurse) that it was too late to take the pill now as I should have taken in on day 2 of the previous month  (I ended up waiting a year, but didn't have to redo the consult)  I opted to order in small doses as needed since I didn't know what my protocol was going to be or how long I would be on stims I was perplexed because days earlier I didn't have a balance at all and confirmed that my insurance still had not reached its cap for fertility treatments  But I believe that this place has the most data, the most information, to base their decisions on  They are way more focused on the next generation than on this one My doc followed up on every procedure, and I knew she was available if neededand I now know why The secretary did not inform us we should schedule the ultrasound appointment with any of the doctors so we waited and then found out we should do that and it was week 8

Disappointed in those results, I researched other practices and doctors in NYC to try to have better results for my last cycle covered by insuranceMedical care was not satisfactory It was too late to cancel without financial penalty, so I went anyway I froze my eggs with NYU in 2012 and it was totally fine I now pay an annual $ 1000 fee to keep my eggs frozen, and I have been told by friends that can transfer them to other services at a cost of $ 1500 for 5 years  I was told that Recombine would accept my insurance - and my insurance did pay them over $1500 for the carrier map testing, but yet I still received a bill from Recombine for over 4 hundreds dollars I was sent a bill of $6950, exactly the cost that was discussed prior to the egg freeze cycle

I slashed my living expenses where I could (iI had my first cycle out of the two covered by insurance done at another practice, which proved to be a waste of time and moneyTerrible billing system Wrong bills to insurance and over charge many times on me Very terrible billing system (Seriously, who has time for all these appointments, having a professional job to pay for this, plus time for yoga classes and acupuncture?) coordinator" Obviously a comment from many patients before meexplain what's going on during this process Your team seems to prescribe a blanket treatment to us, yet every body is different Your dr will also not be the one who does the retrieval After that visit, I was never able to talk to a doctor again I just kept saying, I need to talk to someone, get some information, more medical advice or some follow-up  She is extremely knowledgeable and approachable  I go do the blood work the next morning and I inquire about the clomid    He said he would pass it along to the doctor and his teamI seeming to just raid your insurance and/or wallet  The Dr never explained anything except the obvious and of course if you are new to the process how would you know what questions to ask But I must and options at every turn He is very informative and knowledgeable When I asked questions or for her to explain the next step she gave me attitude as if this is something I should already know Check Our IVF coordinator, Kiran, was so incredible and compassionate! She was able to answer all of our questions usually within hours of emailing her, and stay current throughout our journey  Luckily, I was referred to RMA of New York and I am extremely grateful to Dr Stein and the RMA nurses and staff for their care and support on this journey Vivian, his nurse, as well as all the other nurses I interacted with were kind, compassionate and caring She also commented on the difference in warmth and intimacy at NYU vs RMA and has since told all of her girlfriends to go to NYU instead He also gave a great referral to our OB who delivered our baby last week!  Nurses like Krista and the IFV coordinator Kiran made our lives so much easier while we went through everything She provided the perfect balance of science and compassion as she explained her strategy and approach each visit My hormone cycle was much easier to get a hang of with this reliable and organized location She is a wonderful resource to the company  Everyone at RMA was incredibly responsive to all of our needs, including quick response to all questions over email   Additionally, the nurses and administrative professionals at RMA NY Eastside are top notch  Throughout all my ups and downs at RMA, Dr Copperman and his amazing staff of nurses (Leyla and Jordyn), coordinators (Samantha), and nutritionists (Dara) have been holding my hand the entire time Everyone was really responsive and supportive, answered any and all questions we had  My IVF coordinator Marlene Pena had also been very helpful and responsive to all my questions  Special mention to Miriam, the financial coordinator, who really goes above and beyond her job description5 Stars! My husband and I had a very positive experience with RMA, both with the supporting staff and under the care of Dr Eric Flisser They were all smiles and help when our money was flowing to them like water The doctors are the best at what they do and the nurses are all lovelyyes, it was a nurse because she then called my name and led me to the doctor Kirstin as a coordinator is simply amazing! Coordinator or nurse returned my calls every time I asked, emails were answered promptly as wellMy husband and I had a wonderful -- and most importantly, successful -- experience with RMA of NY I had a lot of questions and needed a lot of reassurance  Both Ashlie and Kirsten  were my cheerleaders and my voice of reason His nurses are also great  The head fertility nurse announced that she "loved email" as a primary means of communication, but then took days to respond  The nurses and my IVF coordinator were always incredibly responsive and helpful Cheryl, Lissandra, Audrey, and Raquel became so special to me over the months with the highs and lows that fertility treatment bringsMy wife and I had a very good experience here with Dr Allison Styne and Amber Madsen was our nurse  Amber was also amazing

Jo Anne, who works in billing, always assists me immediately with requests whether it be paying my balance or paid invoice requests  Especially beware of Hiura, the information she gave me was grossly incorrect Bottom line- there was no sense of communication here All the care about is the money nothing else this is like a cow factory! For me the lack of personal attention was also an issue

I worked with Dr Flisser and his assistants Courtney and Ariel, and all of three of them were exceptionalYour nurses and coordinators are a mixed group She  transferred her file to NYU and they looked at her medications and told her that they didn't make sense for her bodyAfter my first visit, I only spoke to nurses ON THE PHONE If I called her for anything, she always answered my questionsam very displeased with the services that I got from Jovana Leukovich and her staff The nurse tells me she will send the clomid and contact me later in the day with the results of my blood work  The nurse said she will speak to him and call me back   The person who called insisted that the nurse had left all of this information in the voicemail she left  Furthermore her attitude was off putting She didn't explain half the stuff that was listed in this guide they give you, and she was so disorganized and scatterbrained The nurse named Alyssa especially stood out for her personable touch to in-person meetings and calls He also returned calls on evening and weekends when needed His nurse's Ashlie and Kirsten - emailed me almost daily   Angela, the women who handles all of the meds is an absolute savior  Now the staff

Covid interrupted our IVF process and they were great about sharing updates and keeping us informed  - particularly challenging given how little information was available anywhere! A particular word of praise is owed to the nursing staff who are always attentive and gracious The nurses and other physicians were also all so nice and really went the extra mile to make me feel comfortable and fully informed Even through the COVID-19 pandemic, the offices were able to stay open and went to great lengths to ensure every visit was as safe and sanitary as possible RMA is a huge practice with the best fertility specialists in the City - that means the best lab team, the best physicians and nurses, offices around the City, great facilities, and even a social worker for the emotional aspects of the journey A large practice with a huge volume of patients also means that there are very occasional issues with billing, call backs take a couple of hours, and the waiting room can get packed some mornings, if you come in on the later side I know the teams at CCRM and Cornell are wonderful too, but my husband and I recommend RMA without hesitationThey were fantastic, very clean, organized and fully equipped! Dr Sandler and his team is especially nice and efficient! My husband and I had a beautiful baby via IVF and can't be more happy about it Almost as important were his team who worked with me on scheduling and communication on everything from ordering medication to dosages Anyone who has been through this knows how organizationally complex it can be, and Flisser's team were on top of everythingRMA has been absolutely amazing They have been very helpful, understanding, caring and patient This process can be very long and taxing but the team at RMA helps you get through the process with their attentiveness to your needsI also like this practice because they have morning monitoring hours--from 7am to 8:30am you can walk in without making an appointment and still get to work on timeMy wife and I feel very good in this place where they really help you and explain you step by step, thanks to Dr Carlos Hernandez Nieto who made us feel that we are in very good hands Although not every visit was the news we had wanted, their nurses offered so much physical and emotional support as we were going through IVF which was draining and felt like it was going nowhere Although no one wants to pay for fertility ;) their finance team was also great! I never had to call insurance to fight a bill, as everything was explained in detail to me by the team Although an emotional and physical journey, I would come back to this place in a heartbeat Good luck to all of you  hang in there! I hope it works out for all of you The office operates like a well oiled machine, excellent if you are working, I was never there more than 1hr (and that's on a really busy morning) Everyone is very nice from the nurses to the finance team Good luck getting a phone call having someone follow up with you, there is a general number you call were you are placed on hold for a while until they decided to respond everything is put into a computer which leads to many errors and things being incredibly disorganized and there are huge mistakes made in the process however, they will never give it a second glance nor does anyone care to there is a huge cover up system in place when you need your records there is a two week waiting period to have a 15 They get results or positive pregnancies due to volume of around 500+ woman at any given time,however i would not be surprised at all if they artificially inflated the numbers to lure vulnerable women into that place!Your larger desk staff were difficult to engage and generally lacked warmth The Doctors are very good with qualified nurses ready to help any time you call  We are now pregnant and just discharged today!  Very happy customers  His team and the faculty at RMANY is professional, punctual, always smiling, and easy to reach  It was always easy to get in touch with billing with our many questions  This place is busy, especially east side - but don't mistake it for a haphazard baby factory  They truly are the #1 place for fertility issues and I trusted them implicitly They run a busy office but I always felt taken care of and supported I have had many friends go through IVF and the full waiting room is something that comes along with the territory no matter where you go, for the most part I hope somebody has the guts to file a lawsuit, they should be closed down! Please allow me the massive privilege of commenting exclusively on the monitoring experience provided by this RMA location, nothing else Process: Monitoring is clearly done in large batches, but is executed very efficiently There are usually a good 20 women in the waiting room, which plays upbeat pop, has strong WiFi, and offers lots of recent magazines One could comfortably wait quite a while here, but 25 minutes is the maximum I sat through  Pretty impressive! Also explains the sobering 7-8:30 a Personnel: So happy to find that the majority of the staff here are female The nurses are sensitive to the toils of regular blood-testing and gently ask which arm you prefer; the front-desk staff always wish clients a good morning OBGYNs themselves have been a little cold and brief, but never rude Being treated well at 7 a Perhaps it was the lack of stress, the comforting staff, and the manageable time commitment that supported my eventual 40-egg retrieval We have a 9-month-old now after a very very difficult process--but RMA was as helpful and caring as they could be under the circumstances  Both were highly responsive and patient with me as I made decisions and dealt with any setbacksLastly, they were very hands on in helping me navigate my insuranceRMA of NYC (eastside) made my husband and I parents - twice!! The team of doctors and nurses were exceptionally knowledgeable and kind IVF can be a scary time but they always answered all of my (MANY) questions and walked me through each step of the process in great detail We have had a positive experience with the clinic overallI had an excellent experience at RMA The staff at RMA made the whole IVF process as simple as it can be with their organization, resources, and support Some may say that they feel like a number because there are so many patients but it's NYC and that is to be expected Every single staff member that I encountered was wonderful from billing, to coordinators, to nurses, to phlebotomists, to the doctorsEveryone was very helpful and the whole clinic is very LGBT friendly I was referred by a colleague and now would like to question exactly what they saw in this group RMA and it's staff (I mainly went to the Westchester offices except for a couple NYC visits and of course the major prucedures) were wonderful The staff cares and are sensitive to what individuals are going through In the end, as I just got discharged yesterday, it was kind of bittersweet to leave   Things like medical advice, next steps, procedures, side effects, timelines, effectiveness, risks just aren't discussed The nurses were also very sweet and seemed to actually care There is alot of emotion and stress that comes along with IVF, but I felt extremely cared for at RMAI highly recommend Reproductive Medicine Associates of New York The staff is professional, helpful and kind All of the office staff and doctors are knowledgeable and demonstrate that they really care! The entire practice is like a well oiled machine, highly efficient WOW!!! Extremely disappointed with his professionalismWhile RMA of NY was clearly a large facility, it felt like a well oiled machine with wonderful staff - everyone was extraordinarily helpful and friendly  I also like that at RMA, the process now is for your doctor to do the transfer rather than any doctor who is on dutyThe other things I appreciated about RMA are the efficiency with which the office is run and the competent staff  I like that they have a central coordinator for each patient who you can reach out to with any questions - again, other clinics did not have this and you had to deal with different nurses all the time, most of who had no idea who you were or your background  Given that you will be spending a LOT of time at the clinic for monitoring etc, it's also important that the clinic is efficiently run  While it's unavoidable that most clinics will be crowded, I was able to get in and out without having excessive delays by avoiding peak times (go early mornings!)  They do care how long you are waiting and try to avoid situations where you have to wait for very long periods of time - which is more than I can say for the other 2 clinics I have been to  We got pregnant on our first transfer cycle and had a great experience through being released from RMA  Keep up the awesome work!  The nurse calls me later in the day and says my blood work came back fine, but DrFlisser said I have a BMI of 45% and in needs to be below 40 % Rather, my issue with RMA which I feel the need to bring to everyone's attention is with the substandard and disappointing service and care I received  Yet another mess for us to clean up   I am posting my experience with the hopes that RMA take an extensive look at your staff, communication, and billing protocols    However, my doctors and the staff at CCRM in both New York and Colorado have made a challenging situation bearable while providing the quality of care and communication unlike anything I experienced at RMA Also, as someone from the medical field myself, I can appreciate the thoroughness and coordination of the office staff We will definitely be returning when we are ready for #2! Thank you to Dr Flisser, Ariel and the staff at RMA! Get past the overwhelming feeling during morning monitoring - the care I received really was amazing and I highly recommend RMA Eastside  They are interested in stats not helping you grow a family They are ALWAYS available, and truly on this ride with youWe were  very happy at RMA Eastside Rma have great staff always answered all my questions and always called to touch base with me to see how everything is going and they are very professionalI didn't do much research when my doctor recommanded a list of places for IVF, I chose RMA because it was one of the center of excellence for my health insurance company, and also it is easy for commute as I work in the city  I also recall looking up their numbers (successful rate) in the national database, and they looked good compare to others  They treat you like a number, not a personI attended the Broadway office which was very clean, the waiting time was never over 10 min and everything went smoothly That said, had I known to call off cycle, the office  would have - but since I'm going to experts, it would have been nice if they had been proactive and called off the cycleThe staff here is excellent You will find a very caring attention to detail at every interactionThe doctors here are some of the best and you will note the many times each has been noted for their excellence by the many awards for Top Doctors of the year The Dr took us through the whole process, did an ultrasound, made it all sound super easy and hopeful If RMA had done their due diligence we would have saved time and stress and heartache of thinking we couldn't afford to even try Feels like a factory, and with check in visits I've had experiences where the doctor on duty made mistakes that clearly indicated they hadn't read my file Some doctors are okay, but overall it's not a personal experience and you feel more like a number than a patient YOU MUST BE KIDDING ME !!!! YOU HAVE NO FREAKING DOCTORS !!! I literally see 7 listed on your business card !! Good luck to everyone out there still looking for an answer Looks like they were just looking to make money off of unsuspecting patients Walk in, walk out, like machines My first experience at RMA was greatWhy they even hired that kind of people 3 times false information in a row and charged $2,000 on my credit card without my consent which was ridiculous There's lots of better places in NYCRMA is like a high volume uncaring infertility factory who's primary focus is getting money from their desperate clients They treat their patients like patients, not like targets They treat people as a number for something so personal as fertility The only reason I come here is because my OBGYN respects this place, they have lots of traffic and see many cases, their stats are good! That said I wish I had the choice of another place Thanks to them I have 2 beautiful healthy babies  Also, in speaking with many other woman who go through fertility treatment in various clinics in NYC, I learned most of the popular ones have that factory feel as many woman need helpThe staff was great  They were respectful and comforting but I felt that ALL were smart, competent and trustworthy Their nurse called us back the same day after every test and clearly explained the next step and shots that were needed to be done This is very impressive They run it as a business which is fine with me I run a dental office myself so appreciate the organization and professionalismRMA definitely feels like a fertility factory and you won't always get the warm and fuzzies here, but they're on top of it! IVF is a confusing and overwhelming process I always felt I was in good hands here  The doctors and nurses are all so warm & make you feel so comfortable The doctors answer your emails even on the weekends and in the evenings!!  The front staff are great too Dr Azim was great BUT the lab that he uses (Gramercy IVF) has freezers that ruined our sperm quality which was excellent quality from a sperm bank We HIGHLY recommend Sher above all else!!! Don't walk away from RMA, RUN AWAY!!!!  For me, I was happy to be seen by doctors who do this all the time and whose office runs like a well-oiled machine  When I was too chicken to give myself a really simple injection that was meant to be administered at home, they were more than happy for me to bring it to them for a nurse to give me, and I was in and out in five minutes  Their doctors have great reputations but the office side of this operation needs a serious overhaul They acted like I should have already known all the steps in what is actually a pretty complicated processI am very grateful to the RMA staff and the various doctors that I worked with For me this was the most efficient way to get the care I needed Doctor Sandler, all the lab technicians and nurses were more than helpful They gave us bad advice regarding a rebate program (Compassionate Care) that could have saved us literally thousands of dollars  The nurses I worked with ranged from being sufficiently pleasant to totally amazing (with the majority being toward the amazing end of the spectrum) Bloodwork and other tests are turned around with amazing speed (which is necessary in this area of medicine) and although the crowds in the waiting room can be scary at times (esp on weekends) they move things along with surprising speed and efficiency This place is a joke We requested our medical records from the practice because we wanted someone closer to our home in Long Island to follow our care We've since found much more caring and attentive practices and now prefer seeing a doctor who actually will care for you! Difficult as it is to find these days, the effort is worth it They see a lot of patients and move fast as they are a busy place, so have your questions prepared in advance and you will do wellbut I have to agree with the others about it being a cold, emotionless place  It truly is like a factory I 100 percent agree with earlier reviewers who have claimed that it is a factory It is almost impossible to actually speak to a doctor, and while some nurses (Carrie) are great, most of the others seem like they rented their lab coats from a costume shop I never receive any kind of cost breakdown for the services, and am just supposed to trust that their numbers are rightI wish that there were other options out there for womenI've been going here since July 2013 and tried to keep an open mind, but for a practice that handles such important and sensitive work, I've been really disappointed at the complete lack of compassion and care The place is run like a factory - efficient yes, but cold Nurses and doctors alike just want to get you in and out The nurses who have helped me have been mediocre, at best I'm sure this place has been great for many people, but I would not recommend them to any of my friends and felt like I owed it to other women to write this review  Going through a process that is so sensitive this place should feel welcoming but it's notI think the NY office of RMA is amazing  I always felt like I was in excellent hands, even at the time when things were not looking good for us Going through IVF is an emotional roller coaster and I found the staff to be as pleasant and helpful as possible The RN staff is very friendly and always follows up and I can simply request an appointment with Dr M to go over options You mean I was supposed to continue through last night?"  With the snootiest of tones she said "Well that must've been a misinterpretation on YOUR part  Further, the original plan of taking the injection for 3 nights, skipping a night, then coming in 36 hours later for ultrasound/labs didnt make sense such that I called the office BACK to ensure those were the instructions, They were repeated to me in the same way, so that's what I didThe doctors might have good reputations  But, their customer service responses were often slow and less responsive  Every time I received IUI, I was allowed to stay there only 10 minutes and I always felt as if was rushed out While checking out at the NYC office the receptionist were laughing with one another and socializing When I kindly asked for a supervisor I was asked what do you mean a supervisor? We don't have a supervisor I don't think the office workers realize that they are there to help PATIENTS not customers
